1:
It is better to have quiet with a dry morsel of bread\q than a house full of feasting with strife.
\q
2:
A wise servant will rule over a son who acts shamefully\q and will share the inheritance as one of the brothers.

\q
3:
The crucible is for silver and the furnace is for gold,\q but Yahweh refines hearts.
\q
4:
The evildoer pays attention to wicked lips;\q a liar gives ear to a destructive tongue.


\q
5:
Whoever mocks the poor insults his Maker\q and the one who rejoices at misfortune will not go unpunished.
\q
6:
Grandchildren are the crown of the aged\q and parents bring honor to their children.

\q
7:
Eloquent speech is not suitable for a fool;\q much less are lying lips suitable for royalty.
\q
8:
A bribe is like a magic stone to the one who gives it;\q wherever he turns, he succeeds.

\q
9:
Whoever overlooks an offense seeks love,\q but the one who repeats a matter alienates close friends.
\q
10:
A rebuke goes deeper into a person who has understanding\q than a hundred blows go into a fool.


\q
11:
An evil person only seeks rebellion,\q so a cruel messenger will be sent against him.
\q
12:
It is better to meet a bear robbed of her cubs\q than to meet a fool in his foolishness.


\q
13:
When someone returns evil for good,\q evil will never leave his house.
\q
14:
The beginning of conflict is like one who releases water everywhere,\q so walk away from the dispute before it has broken out.


\q
15:
The person who acquits the wicked person and the person who condemns the righteous personâ€”\q both are an abomination to Yahweh.
\q
16:
Why should a fool pay money to learn about wisdom,\q when he has no ability to learn it?


\q
17:
A friend is loving at all times\q and a brother is born for times of trouble.
\q
18:
A man having no sense makes binding promises\q and becomes responsible for his neighbor's debts.

\q
19:
Whoever loves conflict loves sin;\q the one who makes the threshold of his door too high causes bones to be broken.
\q
20:
A person who has a crooked heart finds nothing that is good;\q the one who has a perverse tongue falls into calamity.


\q
21:
Whoever is the parent of a fool brings grief to himself;\q and the father of a fool has no joy.
\q
22:
A cheerful heart is good medicine,\q but a broken spirit dries up the bones.


\q
23:
A wicked man accepts a secret bribe\q to pervert the ways of justice.
\q
24:
The one who has understanding sets his face toward wisdom,\q but the eyes of a fool are set on the ends of the earth.


\q
25:
A foolish son is a grief to his father\q and bitterness to the woman who bore him.
\q
26:
Also, it is never good to punish the righteous person;\q neither is it good to flog noble men who have integrity.


\q
27:
One who has knowledge uses few words\q and one with understanding is even-tempered.
\q
28: Even a fool is thought to be wise if he keeps silent;\q when he keeps his mouth shut, he is considered to be intelligent.
